title: Neil Waugh's Outdoors: A melancholy Oil Patch Christmas
text:
Report an error 
It’s still only October but the festive season comes early to the oil patch south of Lodgepole – although “festive” may be a bad word choice. 
The Christmas trees are draped with a garland of silvery chains, accented with heavy padlocks and the nodding holiday donkeys are mostly stilled in their stalls. 
Instead of a spirit of comfort and joy, this remote corner of the Pembina Oil Field wears a veil of melancholy about it. 
The big, tight formation known as the Cardium sand that underlies the place was first tapped way back in 1953 and many of these wells have been stoically producing oil ever since. 
Relentlessly drawing reluctant black gold from the ground a few cubic centimetres or so each time the pump jack’s walking beam rocks. 
Oil at $100 a barrel helped keep the old wells alive. But now it’s down around $45 and a harsh reality has set in. 
When lifting costs exceed revenues off goes the power and out come the chains. 
And the Christmas trees – Oil Patch-Speak for the stack of pipes and valves bolted to the top of the well bore – are shut-in pending the outcome of a game of economic chicken being played out halfway around the world. 
Of course, anyone in oil and gas knows that booms and busts are part of the DNA. 
But the busts still hurt. 
Unless you’re a ruffed grouse. 
Ruffies and the oil patch share a symbiotic relationship. Oil roads and drilling leases driven though the aspen uplands of west central Alberta have created thousands of kilometres of transitional “edge” where grouse love to hang out. 
While energy companies are mandated to over-seed disturbed ground to prevent erosion. 
These seed mixtures inevitably include red clover. Ruffies in fall gorge on the stuff. 
When revenues are restricted, oil road maintenance and truck traffic declines and the clover crop flourishes even more. 
It’s a perfect storm out there and my bird hunting buddy Emmerson and I are headed out to Lodgepole to hopefully exploit it. 
The cadence of oil roads don’t necessarily follow any logic or pattern. When there’s a road grader up ahead the task of sticking with the path most travelled becomes even more problematic. 
We somehow made it somewhere south of Sand Creek where Emmerson spotted a bird in the ditch. 
I followed it up a hillside and gave it both barrels from my Ruger. I thought it fell on the second shot but neither my fox red Lab Penny nor I could find it. But on the hike down to the Jeep its partner appeared. One shot, one ruffie in the bag. 
Emmerson harvested Flush No. 2. Another road edge bird. 
A good start and the dog hadn’t had a hunt yet. 
An over-gown lease road that led back to some silent wells simply screamed grouse. 
We parked the truck and let the dog out. Penny almost immediately got birdie but when no flush happened we moved on. 
Coming up to a corner, which is a favorite grouse hangout, she cut a hot scent again. 
When the fourth flush came we only caught a glimpse of the fleeing bird. 
A little farther up the trail the dog made game and disappeared on a long hunt back into a cutblock. 
There was a whirr behind us. Grouse five must have crossed the road. 
But the sixth bird wasn’t so wily and it folded when my string of 7 1/2 caught up with it. 
We were shortcutting down an ancient Alberta Gas Trunk Line right-of-way when the seventh flush of the day lifted off. 
Another heard-but-never-seen bird. 
The last bird in the bag fell to Emmerson’s Berretta. When he and Penny went to retrieve it at the road edge two more ruffies flushed. And were mysteriously swallowed up by the forest. 
Bringing the day’s total to 4 for 10. 
Which is not a bad way to celebrate a holly, jolly, melancholy Oil Patch Christmas.
